item.title: Trump Says It’s Likely Russia Knew of Syrian Gas Attack in Advance
item.media:description: President Trump met with Jens Stoltenberg, the NATO secretary general, in the Oval Office on Wednesday.
item.description: The remarks amounted to an explosive suggestion at a time of heightened tension between the United States and Russia after the chemical attack.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and PETER BAKER

item.title: Tillerson and Putin Find Little More Than Disagreement in Meeting
item.description: Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia appeared unable to agree on the facts on contentious issues, much less improve relations.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: The Interpreter: Trump Faces the Limits of American Power
item.media:description: After an airstrike in Douma, Syria, in February. The United States has sought to mediate between the warring parties, or tip the military balance through force.
item.description: In Syria, Nigeria and elsewhere, President Trump has inherited international crises where intervention efforts are likely to have only modest success.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: News Analysis: Trump’s Shift on Russia Brings Geopolitical Whiplash
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia. President Trump’s administration has accused Russia of trying to cover up a Syrian chemical weapons attack on civilians.
item.description: Accusations that President Trump is too close to Russia have given way to a new toughness demonstrated by the administration.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: United Airlines, Syria, Betsy DeVos: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: U.S. State Department, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Asia and Australia Edition: Syria, Ahmadinejad, United Airlines: Your Morning Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES McDERMID

item.title: Trump Undercuts Top Adviser Stephen K. Bannon, Whose Job May Be in Danger
item.media:description: Stephen K. Bannon, President Trump’s chief strategist, during a meeting with the Chinese President Xi Jinping at Mar-a-Lago in Florida last week.
item.description: President Trump said Mr. Bannon was not the chief strategist of his campaign victory, distancing himself from the contentious hard-right adviser who is increasingly isolated in the White House.
item.dc:creator: JEREMY W. PETERS and MAGGIE HABERMAN

item.title: ‘I Screwed Up’: Sean Spicer Apologizes for Holocaust Comments
item.media:description: Sean Spicer, the White House press secretary, said on Wednesday that he “made a mistake” in his comments on the Holocaust the day before.
item.description: Facing an outcry that included calls for his resignation, Mr. Spicer said his remarks, in which he favorably compared Hitler to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, were “inexcusable.”
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL M. GRYNBAUM

item.title: Scott Pruitt Faces Anger From Right Over E.P.A. Finding He Won’t Fight
item.media:description: Traffic in New York City. Conservative groups want Scott Pruitt, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, to overturn a ruling known as the endangerment finding, which provides the legal foundation for the Obama administration’s climate-change policies.
item.description: Critics charge the agency’s administrator should have challenged a legal finding that underpinned the Obama climate policies, but he refuses to budge.
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT

item.title: Your Daily Mini Crossword
item.description: Solve a bite-size crossword in just a few minutes.

item.title: Ham or Lamb? The Easter Choice May Be Changing
item.description: Unlike the rest of the world, Americans turn to pork for the holiday. But this could be the year to start looking at another meat.
item.dc:creator: KIM SEVERSON

item.title: Tech We're Using: The Apps That Make Keeping Up With Soccer Easier
item.media:description: Rory Smith using his Apple iPad outside Stamford Bridge, home of Chelsea FC, in London.
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.description: The video-streaming apps Virgin Anywhere and Sky Sports Mobile TV are a boon for a soccer reporter, or a fan.
item.dc:creator: RORY SMITH

item.title: Phys Ed: Why Deep Breathing May Keep Us Calm
item.description: Scientists may have uncovered for the first time why taking deep breaths can be so calming.
item.dc:creator: GRETCHEN REYNOLDS

item.title: Turkey in Turmoil and Chaos Since Purge Aimed at Dissenters
item.media:description: A sign in Istanbul asks for yes votes on Sunday in a referendum that would expand the powers of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, who is pictured on the sign.
item.description: The government has fired or suspended about 130,000 people suspected of being dissidents from the public and private sectors since a coup attempt last summer.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Suburban G.O.P. Voters Sour on Party, Raising Republican Fears for 2018
item.media:description: Judson Hill, a Republican candidate in Georgia’s Sixth Congressional District, made calls at his campaign headquarters in Sandy Springs, an Atlanta suburb, on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Kevin D. Liles for The New York Times
item.description: A narrower-than-expected victory in Kansas and an even tougher contest next week in Georgia are highlighting Republicans’ troubles with affluent white voters.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDER BURNS and JONATHAN MARTIN

item.title: Political Calculus: A Republican Wins in Kansas. It’s Still a Loss for the G.O.P.
item.media:description: In the final days, Republicans started to get nervous about Tuesday’s election in Kansas. Senator Ted Cruz, left, tried to bolster the Republican congressional candidate Ron Estes, right, with a visit, and President Trump and Vice President Mike Pence made robocalls on his behalf. Mr. Estes wound up winning, but by a modest margin in a deep-red district.
item.media:credit: Fernando Salazar/The Wichita Eagle, via Associated Press
item.description: A surprisingly close seven-point victory in a deep-red district suggests that the G.O.P. is heading for trouble in 2018.
item.dc:creator: NATE COHN

item.title: How to Write TV in the Age of Trump: Showrunners Reveal All
item.media:credit: Illustration by Ben Wiseman. Photos by Kevin Winter/Getty Images; Steve Sands/GC Images; Byron Cohen/ABC, via Getty Images; Sarah Shatz/CBS, via Getty Images.
item.description: Shonda Rhimes of “Scandal” and the people behind “Veep,” “Madam Secretary” and “House of Cards” talk about reality bumping into fiction.
item.dc:creator: JIM RUTENBERG

item.title: State of the Art: How Technology Has Failed to Improve Your Airline Experience
item.media:description: United Airlines planes at San Francisco International Airport. Oscar Munoz, United’s chief executive, offered an apology and pledged to review the airline’s policies two days after a passenger was violently ejected from an overbooked flight.
item.description: Silicon Valley prides itself on its capacity to upend entrenched industries. But airlines have eluded tech disruption.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO

item.title: United Grapples With PR Crisis Over Videos of Man Being Dragged Off Plane
item.description: The videos cast an unwelcome light not just on United, but on the airline industry’s efforts to maximize profits.
item.dc:creator: JULIE CRESWELL and SAPNA MAHESHWARI

item.title: Update: In the Air, That Uneasy Feeling of ‘Us vs. Them’
item.media:description: When airlines reinvented themselves, some services, like checked bags and meals, became pay-per-use options.
item.description: How the airline industry and passengers came to find themselves navigating unfriendly skies.
item.dc:creator: ELAINE GLUSAC

item.title: Is This China’s Fountain of Youth?
item.description: With the number of older people on the rise in China, longevity-themed tourism is blossoming. Take a 360 tour of Bama County, where visitors breathe in the air that is said to have healing powers.

item.title: Letter Found After Borussia Dortmund Bus Attack Demands Pullback in Syria
item.media:description: Security on Wednesday at the site in Dortmund, Germany, where the Borussia Dortmund team bus was damaged in an explosion.
item.description: Two people with an “Islamist background” were held after the attack on the soccer team’s bus, the German Federal Prosecutor’s Office said.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Venezuela Staves Off Default, but Low Oil Prices Pose a Threat
item.media:description: A demonstration this month in Caracas against the government of President Nicolás Maduro. With its oil production and international reserves falling, the government is struggling to pay for imported medicine and food.
item.description: With dwindling reserves and political turmoil, the government is juggling assets and leaning on its American subsidiary, Citgo, to meet payment needs.
item.dc:creator: CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: For Alabama Christians, Governor Bentley’s Downfall Is a Bitter Blow
item.media:description: Robert Bentley resigned as governor on Monday and pleaded guilty to two misdemeanors in the wake of a sex scandal.
item.media:credit: Bob Miller for The New York Times
item.description: When Robert Bentley became Alabama’s governor, evangelical Christians hoped he would be a model of integrity. On Monday, he resigned after a sex scandal.
item.dc:creator: ALAN BLINDER

item.title: J. Geils, Whose Band’s Catchy Pop Hits Colored the 1980s, Dies at 71
item.media:description: J. Geils and Danny Klein of the J. Geils Band performing in 1972 in Copenhagen.
item.description: “Centerfold,” “Freeze-Frame” and “Love Stinks” were among the band’s most popular songs.
item.dc:creator: NIRAJ CHOKSHI

item.title: David Letterman's Mom, Who Became Unlikely Star, Dies at 95
item.description: David Letterman's mother Dorothy Mengering, a Midwestern homemaker who became an unlikely celebrity in her 70s as she baked mystery pies and covered the Olympics for her son's late-night show, has died. She was 95.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: The Interpreter
item.description: The Interpreter brings sharp insight and context to the major news stories of the week. Sign up to get it by email.

item.title: Lula and Simba, Last Surviving Animals at Mosul Zoo, Have Been Rescued
item.media:description: Lula, a bear from the zoo in Mosul, after arriving at an animal rehabilitation shelter in Jordan.
item.description: Lula, a bear, and Simba, a lion, were taken to a wildlife shelter in Jordan after being saved from their home, which was severely damaged in battles for control of the city.
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS

item.title: ‘Fantastic Beasts’ Has a New Dumbledore: Jude Law
item.media:description: Michael Gambon as Albus Dumbledore in “Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince” (2009).
item.description: The actor will play a younger version of the professor in the next installment of J.K. Rowling’s franchise.
item.dc:creator: CARA BUCKLEY
item.category: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (Movie)

item.title: Bill Cosby’s Books Join ‘Most Challenged’ List
item.media:description: One of the titles in Bill Cosby’s “Little Bill” book series.
item.description: There have been calls for the removal of Mr. Cosby’s children’s book series from schools and libraries.
item.dc:creator: GRAHAM BOWLEY

item.title: European Court Strikes Down Required Sterilization for Transgender People
item.media:description: A gay pride parade in Paris in 2013. Gay and transgender activists in Europe have argued that a sterilization requirement of transgender people was an institutionalized violation of human rights.
item.description: Activists celebrated the ruling, though it does not mean immediate legal change in the countries that require sterilization.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Commissioner Starts to Press Cleveland Indians About Logo
item.media:description: Edwin Encarnacion of the Indians being introduced before Cleveland’s home opener against the Chicago White Sox on Tuesday. The Chief Wahoo logo could not be seen anywhere on the stadium building or on the field, but it was on the players’ jerseys and caps.
item.media:credit: Ken Blaze/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.description: In a statement, Rob Manfred was said to have expressed a desire “to transition away from the Chief Wahoo logo,” a smiling caricature the team uses that many find offensive.
item.dc:creator: DAVID WALDSTEIN

item.title: Student Charged With Hazing in Peanut Butter Allergy Case
item.media:description: A college student has been charged with hazing after allegedly smearing peanut butter on a friend who had a severe peanut allergy, the man’s lawyer said.
item.description: A college student was charged after another student with a serious peanut allergy passed out at an off-campus party and woke up with peanut butter on his face.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Burger King TV Ad Asks, Hoping Google Home Devices Answer
item.description: The commercial is a novel but potentially invasive marketing tactic that comes as more Americans use smart speakers in their homes.
item.dc:creator: SAPNA MAHESHWARI

item.title: Trilobites: A Lizard With Scales That Behave Like a Computer Simulation
item.media:description: An ocellated lizard. Their scales change from brown and white to black and green as they get older, and scientists say they appear to follow a pattern that is similar to a computer simulation.
item.description: Two mathematical models converge to illuminate the process through which an ocellated lizard’s scales repeatedly change color.
item.dc:creator: STEPH YIN

item.title: An Appraisal: How David Letterman’s Mother Endeared Him to Viewers
item.media:description: Dorothy Mengering during a taping of “Late Show” in 1996, with the bandleader Paul Shaffer, center, and her son, David Letterman.
item.description: Dorothy Mengering, who died on Tuesday, was a perfect comic foil, softening her son’s bite and eventually becoming his show’s recurring correspondent.
item.dc:creator: JASON ZINOMAN
item.category: Late Night With David Letterman (TV Program)
Late Show With David Letterman (TV Program)

item.title: Works in Progress: Hoping Cherry Blossoms Won’t Arrive Early to Their Own Party
item.media:description: Brian Funk, a specialist of cherry trees at Brooklyn Botanic Gardens. Administrators there hope peak blooming coincides with the annual festival at the end of April.
item.media:credit: Ryan Christopher Jones for The New York Times
item.description: The annual festival at Brooklyn Botanic Garden takes place at the end of April — regardless of when nature decides to push play.
item.dc:creator: HELENE STAPINSKI

item.title: People Like Us: Why Americans Vote ‘Against Their Interest’: Partisanship
item.media:description: Kyle Lloyd, 40, wore a painted “Dump Trump” message at a protest in Philadelphia in January.
item.description: For voters in the United States, party affiliation is a way to express a bundle of identities.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB
